comment_text.dn5:1.1: When asked about sacrifice, the Buddha tells a story of how a king was persuaded to forgo cruelty and institute a constructive social policy of welfare instead.
comment_text.dn5:1.2: Khāṇumata is only mentioned here. It means “stumpy”, perhaps indicating that it was, or had recently been, a rough out-of-the-way place.
comment_text.dn5:1.3: The commentary says this was similar to the Ambalaṭṭhikā of DN 1:1.2.1.
comment_text.dn5:1.4: Like the town Khāṇumata, the brahmin Kūṭadanta appears only here. His name means “pointy teeth”, but there is no evidence that he was a vampire.
comment_text.dn5:1.6: At Snp 2.7:26.1, the sacrifice of cows in particular was said to be the nadir of decline for brahmins. When similar sacrifices are described elsewhere in the canon, the number is five hundred rather than seven hundred (SN 3.9:1.2, AN 7.47:1.2).
comment_text.dn5:4.3: News of the Buddha had spread in Brahmanical circles. In DN 3 we saw the Buddha use his rhetorical technique of adapting his teaching to reframe Brahmanical doctrines in order to establish a common ground. Here we see the downside to such techniques, as the details of the reframing have been lost.
comment_text.dn5:4.6: No such sacrifice has been identified in Brahmanical texts.
comment_text.dn5:9.7: Kūṭadanta’s proposal that the Buddha advise him on the sacrifice of 700 animals is outrageous. Nonetheless, the Buddha responds politely since Kūṭadanta is being polite. While it is tempting to see the sacrifice of animals by supposedly virtuous priests as sheer hypocrisy, the fact of sacrifice remains one of the most widespread and mysterious of human religious practices. In an empathetic work that addresses this squarely, Roberto Calasso’s Ardor sees the vast complex of Vedic ritual and theory as making plain the fact of killing so that the guilt may be contained, in contrast with our modern culture of killing on an industrial scale while hiding it out of sight.
comment_text.dn5:10.1: Mahāvijita means “Great Dominion”. He seems to be only known from this story. The idiom bhūtapubbaṁ (literally “so it was in the past”) introduces legendary narratives of usually dubious historicity, like the English idiom “once upon a time”.
comment_text.dn5:10.2: In the Pali, meaningful thoughts often occur to people when withdrawn in seclusion. This doesn’t necessary mean they were in formal meditation.
comment_text.dn5:10.3: The great sacrifices, especially the horse sacrifice, ensured royal authority. Their very scale and wastefulness showed off the wealth of the king.
comment_text.dn5:10.4: “High priest” is purohita. He was a family chaplain advising and consecrating the royal family. The closeness of the relationship is shown by the fact that the royal family would take the lineage name of the purohita.
comment_text.dn5:11.2: Then, as today, government policy was driven by the perception of rising crime rate. This whole passage is one of the Buddha’s most important statements on public policy. It is expressed through storytelling, giving a good example of how myths were invoked—and subverted—as rationales for current policy.
comment_text.dn5:11.3: “Taxes” is bali. He would have had to press his people for the extra funds to hold the sacrifice.
comment_text.dn5:11.5: “Plague of savages” (dassukhīla) is the only occurrence of Sanskrit dasyu in early Pali. The dasyu were inveterate foes of the Aryans in the Vedic period. Bereft of civilizing rites, scriptures, and observances, they were no children of Manu (Rig Veda 10.22.8). Their wiles (māyā) made them a potent threat (Rig Veda 4.16.9, 8.14.14, 10.73.5). Indra was invoked to ensure their destruction (Rig Veda passim; Atharva Veda 2.14.5, 4.32.3, 20.21.4, 20.37.5, 20.42.2). Legend has it that Agni and Soma first supported the dasyu before being won over by Indra (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.6.3.13; see also 6.4.2.4). By the time of the Buddha the dasyu have vanished except as a legendary foe of the past. Where the Brahmanical texts advocate the pitiless destruction of the dasyu, the brahmin high priest in the Buddhist text advocates an inclusive policy of social welfare.
comment_text.dn5:11.6: The priest knows that the king will respond better to a pragmatic argument than a moral one.
comment_text.dn5:11.7: Effective social policy requires a forward-thinking plan, not just reacting to grievances.
comment_text.dn5:11.8: The king should spend his own resources to support his citizens in the various occupations.
comment_text.dn5:11.11: Here the priest identifies a fundamental cause of social unrest and disorder.
comment_text.dn5:11.12: The king spends out of pocket, but the economy flourishes, so tax revenues increase even though he has not raised taxes. This is the essence of Keynesian economic theory.
comment_text.dn5:11.13: Khema means a place of safety and sanctuary, where both humans and animals have no fear.
comment_text.dn5:11.14: A good leader listens to advice.
comment_text.dn5:12.1: Here the phrase “of both town and country” qualifies each group. At AN 4.70:1.3, however, “brahmins and householders” and “people of town and country” are separate groups of people. Elsewhere the context does not always decide between these two possibilities. Generally the idiom aims at inclusivity, as opposed to here where the king is consulting the rich and powerful, so I treat them as two separate groups, thus including the common folk.
comment_text.dn5:12.9: “Consenting factions” is anumatipakkhā. The king governs with the consent of his people, although only the landowning classes are considered.
comment_text.dn5:13.1: Royal authority is not based just on birth, conquest, ritual, or power, but on quality of character.
comment_text.dn5:13.5: Read sahati (“prevails”) over the several variants.
comment_text.dn5:13.7: Showing the importance of comprehension over blind adherence to tradition.
comment_text.dn5:13.9: Meditators focus on the present, but that does not mean they cannot think about the past or future; it just means they are not trapped in useless thoughts.
comment_text.dn5:14.1: These are four of the five qualities that Soṇadaṇḍa identifies as the qualities of a brahmin at DN 4:13.2. Missing is appearance, which is the first factor that Soṇadaṇḍa admits is unnecessary.
comment_text.dn5:15.3: Compare the three factors of a donor’s mind-state at AN 6.37:2.4.
comment_text.dn5:16.1: What a recipient does with a gift is beyond the donor’s control.
comment_text.dn5:16.4: PTS edition acknowledges sajjata only as a variant reading, but it is in the commentary, so should be accepted in the text. It is from √sajj (relinquish).
comment_text.dn5:17.3: Another lesson in leadership: the importance of communication.
comment_text.dn5:17.11: Due to abbreviation, the text only mentions householders here, but clearly all are intended.
comment_text.dn5:18.3: A leader gets results through inspiration, not fear.
comment_text.dn5:18.5: These were regarded as valuable yet harmless products.
comment_text.dn5:19.2: The king’s generosity and sincerity brings out the best in the others.
comment_text.dn5:21.1: Here ends the Buddha’s legendary account of the past.
comment_text.dn5:21.3: The other brahmins are satisfied, but Kūṭadanta senses there is more to it.
comment_text.dn5:21.10: “So I have heard” (evaṁ me sutaṁ) is the standard opening for Buddhist suttas. This tag was used to indicate that the speaker was not present at the events, but “heard” about them. This is in contrast with the phrase “I heard and learned this in the presence” (sammukhā sutaṁ, sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ), which is used when reporting a teaching heard directly from the Buddha, eg. SN 55.52:5.1, SN 22.90:9.1, MN 47:10.7, etc.
comment_text.dn5:21.16: This qualifies the story of Mahāvijita as an early canonical Jātaka. There are a small number of such stories in the early suttas, only some of which overlap with the later Jātaka collections, the story of Mahāvijita not being among them.
comment_text.dn5:22.1: Kūṭadanta is hoping for a better return on his investment. Throughout the suttas, we find a strain of what might be called “spiritual economics”.
comment_text.dn5:22.4: The anukula (“propitious”) sacrifice is mentioned several times (eg. DN 5:22.4, AN 4.40:2.2). The Pali commentaries interpret it as “in line with (anu-) family (kula)”. But nothing in the contexts connects it with family customs, nor is such a term known in Sanskrit. It seems rather to be a misunderstanding of Sanskrit anukūla, literally “along the riverbank”, and in applied use, “in conformity with”, “favorable to”, as in the favor of the gods. This is the standard reading in Buddhist Sanskrit. Such a sacrifice is characterized, not by family custom, but by harmlessness. Thus anukula means “propitious, favored (by the gods and the Dhamma)”.
comment_text.dn5:23.4: This contradicts the description given above.
comment_text.dn5:24.4: This means that the dwelling could be used by any Saṅgha member, as opposed to being given to a particular monastic or group. The gift of a dwelling is regarded as the best kind of offering to the Saṅgha.
comment_text.dn5:26.5: Thus far the Buddha has described the regular practice of a Buddhist lay person.
comment_text.dn5:27.16: The entire path may be described as a “sacrifice”.
comment_text.dn5:28.6: Releasing animals remains a Buddhist practice today.

root_text.dn5:7.25: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo catunnaṁ parisānaṁ sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito …pe…
root_text.dn5:7.26: Samaṇe khalu, bho, gotame bahū devā ca manussā ca abhippasannā …pe…
root_text.dn5:7.27: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo yasmiṁ gāme vā nigame vā paṭivasati na tasmiṁ gāme vā nigame vā amanussā manusse viheṭhenti …pe…
root_text.dn5:7.28: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo saṅghī gaṇī gaṇācariyo puthutitthakarānaṁ aggamakkhāyati, yathā kho pana, bho, etesaṁ samaṇabrāhmaṇānaṁ yathā vā tathā vā yaso samudāgacchati, na hevaṁ samaṇassa gotamassa yaso samudāgato.
root_text.dn5:7.29: Atha kho anuttarāya vijjācaraṇasampadāya samaṇassa gotamassa yaso samudāgato …pe…
root_text.dn5:7.30: Samaṇaṁ khalu, bho, gotamaṁ rājā māgadho seniyo bimbisāro saputto sabhariyo sapariso sāmacco pāṇehi saraṇaṁ gato …pe…
root_text.dn5:7.31: Samaṇaṁ khalu, bho, gotamaṁ rājā pasenadi kosalo saputto sabhariyo sapariso sāmacco pāṇehi saraṇaṁ gato …pe…
root_text.dn5:7.32: Samaṇaṁ khalu, bho, gotamaṁ brāhmaṇo pokkharasāti saputto sabhariyo sapariso sāmacco pāṇehi saraṇaṁ gato …pe…
root_text.dn5:7.33: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo rañño māgadhassa seniyassa bimbisārassa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito …pe…
root_text.dn5:7.34: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo rañño pasenadissa kosalassa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito …pe…
root_text.dn5:7.35: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo brāhmaṇassa pokkharasātissa sakkato garukato mānito pūjito apacito …pe…
root_text.dn5:7.36: Samaṇo khalu, bho, gotamo khāṇumataṁ anuppatto khāṇumate viharati ambalaṭṭhikāyaṁ.
root_text.dn5:7.37: Ye kho pana, bho, keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā amhākaṁ gāmakhettaṁ āgacchanti, atithī no te honti.
root_text.dn5:7.38: Atithī kho panamhehi sakkātabbā garukātabbā mānetabbā pūjetabbā apacetabbā.
root_text.dn5:7.39: Yampi, bho, samaṇo gotamo khāṇumataṁ anuppatto khāṇumate viharati ambalaṭṭhikāyaṁ, atithimhākaṁ samaṇo gotamo.
root_text.dn5:7.40: Atithi kho panamhehi sakkātabbo garukātabbo mānetabbo pūjetabbo apacetabbo.
root_text.dn5:7.41: Imināpaṅgena nārahati so bhavaṁ gotamo amhākaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṁ.
root_text.dn5:7.42: Atha kho mayameva arahāma taṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamituṁ.
root_text.dn5:7.43: Ettake kho ahaṁ, bho, tassa bhoto gotamassa vaṇṇe pariyāpuṇāmi, no ca kho so bhavaṁ gotamo ettakavaṇṇo.
root_text.dn5:7.45: Evaṁ vutte, te brāhmaṇā kūṭadantaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.dn5:7.46: “yathā kho bhavaṁ kūṭadanto samaṇassa gotamassa vaṇṇe bhāsati, ito cepi so bhavaṁ gotamo yojanasate viharati, alameva saddhena kulaputtena dassanāya upasaṅkamituṁ api puṭosenā”ti.
root_text.dn5:7.47: “Tena hi, bho, sabbeva mayaṁ samaṇaṁ gotamaṁ dassanāya upasaṅkamissāmā”ti.
root_text.dn5:8.1: Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo mahatā brāhmaṇagaṇena saddhiṁ yena ambalaṭṭhikā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.dn5:8.2: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.dn5:8.3: Khāṇumatakāpi kho brāhmaṇagahapatikā appekacce bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu; appekacce bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodiṁsu, sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu; appekacce yena bhagavā tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu; appekacce nāmagottaṁ sāvetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu; appekacce tuṇhībhūtā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
root_text.dn5:9.1: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn5:9.4: Na kho panāhaṁ jānāmi tividhaṁ yaññasampadaṁ soḷasaparikkhāraṁ.
root_text.dn5:9.6: Sādhu me bhavaṁ gotamo tividhaṁ yaññasampadaṁ soḷasaparikkhāraṁ desetū”ti.
root_text.dn5:9.7: “Tena hi, brāhmaṇa, suṇāhi sādhukaṁ manasikarohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
root_text.dn5:9.8: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo bhagavato paccassosi.
root_text.dn5:10.1: “bhūtapubbaṁ, brāhmaṇa, rājā mahāvijito nāma ahosi aḍḍho mahaddhano mahābhogo pahūtajātarūparajato pahūtavittūpakaraṇo pahūtadhanadhañño paripuṇṇakosakoṭṭhāgāro.
root_text.dn5:10.2: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, rañño mahāvijitassa rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṁ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
root_text.dn5:10.3: ‘adhigatā kho me vipulā mānusakā bhogā, mahantaṁ pathavimaṇḍalaṁ abhivijiya ajjhāvasāmi, yannūnāhaṁ mahāyaññaṁ yajeyyaṁ, yaṁ mama assa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.
root_text.dn5:10.4: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, rājā mahāvijito purohitaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ āmantetvā etadavoca:
root_text.dn5:10.5: ‘idha mayhaṁ, brāhmaṇa, rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṁ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
root_text.dn5:10.6: “adhigatā kho me vipulā mānusakā bhogā, mahantaṁ pathavimaṇḍalaṁ abhivijiya ajjhāvasāmi. Yannūnāhaṁ mahāyaññaṁ yajeyyaṁ yaṁ mama assa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā”ti.
root_text.dn5:10.8: Anusāsatu maṁ bhavaṁ yaṁ mama assa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.
root_text.dn5:11.1: Evaṁ vutte, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rājānaṁ mahāvijitaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn5:11.2: ‘bhoto kho rañño janapado sakaṇṭako sauppīḷo, gāmaghātāpi dissanti, nigamaghātāpi dissanti, nagaraghātāpi dissanti, panthaduhanāpi dissanti.
root_text.dn5:11.3: Bhavaṁ kho pana rājā evaṁ sakaṇṭake janapade sauppīḷe balimuddhareyya, akiccakārī assa tena bhavaṁ rājā.
root_text.dn5:11.4: Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño evamassa:
root_text.dn5:11.5: “ahametaṁ dassukhīlaṁ vadhena vā bandhena vā jāniyā vā garahāya vā pabbājanāya vā samūhanissāmī”ti, na kho panetassa dassukhīlassa evaṁ sammā samugghāto hoti.
root_text.dn5:11.6: Ye te hatāvasesakā bhavissanti, te pacchā rañño janapadaṁ viheṭhessanti.
root_text.dn5:11.7: Api ca kho idaṁ saṁvidhānaṁ āgamma evametassa dassukhīlassa sammā samugghāto hoti.
root_text.dn5:11.8: Tena hi bhavaṁ rājā ye bhoto rañño janapade ussahanti kasigorakkhe, tesaṁ bhavaṁ rājā bījabhattaṁ anuppadetu.
root_text.dn5:11.9: Ye bhoto rañño janapade ussahanti vāṇijjāya, tesaṁ bhavaṁ rājā pābhataṁ anuppadetu.
root_text.dn5:11.10: Ye bhoto rañño janapade ussahanti rājaporise, tesaṁ bhavaṁ rājā bhattavetanaṁ pakappetu.
root_text.dn5:11.11: Te ca manussā sakammapasutā rañño janapadaṁ na viheṭhessanti;
root_text.dn5:11.13: Khemaṭṭhitā janapadā akaṇṭakā anuppīḷā. Manussā mudā modamānā ure putte naccentā apārutagharā maññe viharissantī’ti.
root_text.dn5:11.14: ‘Evaṁ, bho’ti kho, brāhmaṇa, rājā mahāvijito purohitassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā ye rañño janapade ussahiṁsu kasigorakkhe, tesaṁ rājā mahāvijito bījabhattaṁ anuppadāsi.
root_text.dn5:11.15: Ye ca rañño janapade ussahiṁsu vāṇijjāya, tesaṁ rājā mahāvijito pābhataṁ anuppadāsi.
root_text.dn5:11.16: Ye ca rañño janapade ussahiṁsu rājaporise, tesaṁ rājā mahāvijito bhattavetanaṁ pakappesi.
root_text.dn5:11.17: Te ca manussā sakammapasutā rañño janapadaṁ na viheṭhiṁsu, mahā ca rañño rāsiko ahosi.
root_text.dn5:11.18: Khemaṭṭhitā janapadā akaṇṭakā anuppīḷā manussā mudā modamānā ure putte naccentā apārutagharā maññe vihariṁsu.
root_text.dn5:11.19: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, rājā mahāvijito purohitaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ āmantetvā etadavoca:
root_text.dn5:11.20: ‘samūhato kho me bhoto dassukhīlo, bhoto saṁvidhānaṁ āgamma mahā ca me rāsiko.
root_text.dn5:11.21: Khemaṭṭhitā janapadā akaṇṭakā anuppīḷā manussā mudā modamānā ure putte naccentā apārutagharā maññe viharanti.
root_text.dn5:11.23: Anusāsatu maṁ bhavaṁ yaṁ mama assa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.

root_text.dn5:12.2: ‘icchāmahaṁ, bho, mahāyaññaṁ yajituṁ, anujānantu me bhavanto yaṁ mama assa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.
root_text.dn5:12.3: ‘Evaṁ, bho’ti kho, brāhmaṇa, rājā mahāvijito purohitassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā ye rañño janapade khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, te rājā mahāvijito āmantesi:
root_text.dn5:12.4: ‘icchāmahaṁ, bho, mahāyaññaṁ yajituṁ, anujānantu me bhavanto yaṁ mama assa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.
root_text.dn5:12.6: Ye rañño janapade amaccā pārisajjā negamā ceva jānapadā ca …pe… brāhmaṇamahāsālā negamā ceva jānapadā ca …pe… gahapatinecayikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, te rājā mahāvijito āmantesi:
root_text.dn5:12.7: ‘icchāmahaṁ, bho, mahāyaññaṁ yajituṁ. Anujānantu me bhavanto yaṁ mama assa dīgharattaṁ hitāya sukhāyā’ti.
root_text.dn5:12.9: Itime cattāro anumatipakkhā tasseva yaññassa parikkhārā bhavanti.

root_text.dn5:13.9: paṇḍito, viyatto, medhāvī, paṭibalo, atītānāgatapaccuppanne atthe cintetuṁ.
root_text.dn5:13.11: Iti imānipi aṭṭhaṅgāni tasseva yaññassa parikkhārā bhavanti.
root_text.dn5:14.2: ubhato sujāto mātito ca pitito ca saṁsuddhagahaṇiko yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena;

root_text.dn5:15.1: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa pubbeva yaññā tisso vidhā desesi.
root_text.dn5:15.2: Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṁ yiṭṭhukāmassa kocideva vippaṭisāro:
root_text.dn5:15.3: ‘“mahā vata me bhogakkhandho vigacchissatī”ti, so bhotā raññā vippaṭisāro na karaṇīyo.
root_text.dn5:15.4: Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṁ yajamānassa kocideva vippaṭisāro:
root_text.dn5:15.5: “mahā vata me bhogakkhandho vigacchatī”ti, so bhotā raññā vippaṭisāro na karaṇīyo.
root_text.dn5:15.6: Siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṁ yiṭṭhassa kocideva vippaṭisāro:
root_text.dn5:15.7: “mahā vata me bhogakkhandho vigato”ti, so bhotā raññā vippaṭisāro na karaṇīyo’ti.
root_text.dn5:15.8: Imā kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa pubbeva yaññā tisso vidhā desesi.
root_text.dn5:16.1: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa pubbeva yaññā dasahākārehi paṭiggāhakesu vippaṭisāraṁ paṭivinesi.
root_text.dn5:16.2: ‘Āgamissanti kho bhoto yaññaṁ pāṇātipātinopi pāṇātipātā paṭiviratāpi.
root_text.dn5:16.4: Ye tattha pāṇātipātā paṭiviratā, te ārabbha yajataṁ bhavaṁ, sajjataṁ bhavaṁ, modataṁ bhavaṁ, cittameva bhavaṁ antaraṁ pasādetu.
root_text.dn5:16.5: Āgamissanti kho bhoto yaññaṁ adinnādāyinopi adinnādānā paṭiviratāpi …pe…
root_text.dn5:16.15: Ye tattha sammādiṭṭhikā, te ārabbha yajataṁ bhavaṁ, sajjataṁ bhavaṁ, modataṁ bhavaṁ, cittameva bhavaṁ antaraṁ pasādetū’ti.
root_text.dn5:16.16: Imehi kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa pubbeva yaññā dasahākārehi paṭiggāhakesu vippaṭisāraṁ paṭivinesi.
root_text.dn5:17.1: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, purohito brāhmaṇo rañño mahāvijitassa mahāyaññaṁ yajamānassa soḷasahākārehi cittaṁ sandassesi samādapesi samuttejesi sampahaṁsesi
root_text.dn5:17.2: siyā kho pana bhoto rañño mahāyaññaṁ yajamānassa kocideva vattā:

root_text.dn5:18.1: Tasmiṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, yaññe neva gāvo haññiṁsu, na ajeḷakā haññiṁsu, na kukkuṭasūkarā haññiṁsu, na vividhā pāṇā saṅghātaṁ āpajjiṁsu, na rukkhā chijjiṁsu yūpatthāya, na dabbhā lūyiṁsu barihisatthāya.
root_text.dn5:18.2: Yepissa ahesuṁ dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā, tepi na daṇḍatajjitā na bhayatajjitā na assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni akaṁsu.
root_text.dn5:18.3: Atha kho ye icchiṁsu, te akaṁsu, ye na icchiṁsu, na te akaṁsu;
root_text.dn5:18.4: yaṁ icchiṁsu, taṁ akaṁsu, yaṁ na icchiṁsu, na taṁ akaṁsu.
root_text.dn5:19.1: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, amaccā pārisajjā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, brāhmaṇamahāsālā negamā ceva jānapadā ca, gahapatinecayikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca pahūtaṁ sāpateyyaṁ ādāya rājānaṁ mahāvijitaṁ upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṁsu:
root_text.dn5:19.2: ‘idaṁ, deva, pahūtaṁ sāpateyyaṁ devaññeva uddissābhataṁ, taṁ devo paṭiggaṇhātū’ti.
root_text.dn5:19.3: ‘Alaṁ, bho, mamāpidaṁ pahūtaṁ sāpateyyaṁ dhammikena balinā abhisaṅkhataṁ;
root_text.dn5:19.4: tañca vo hotu, ito ca bhiyyo harathā’ti.
root_text.dn5:19.5: Te raññā paṭikkhittā ekamantaṁ apakkamma evaṁ samacintesuṁ:
root_text.dn5:19.6: ‘na kho etaṁ amhākaṁ patirūpaṁ, yaṁ mayaṁ imāni sāpateyyāni punadeva sakāni gharāni paṭihareyyāma.
root_text.dn5:19.7: Rājā kho mahāvijito mahāyaññaṁ yajati, handassa mayaṁ anuyāgino homā’ti.
root_text.dn5:20.1: Atha kho, brāhmaṇa, puratthimena yaññavāṭassa khattiyā ānuyantā negamā ceva jānapadā ca dānāni paṭṭhapesuṁ.
root_text.dn5:20.2: Dakkhiṇena yaññavāṭassa amaccā pārisajjā negamā ceva jānapadā ca dānāni paṭṭhapesuṁ.
root_text.dn5:20.3: Pacchimena yaññavāṭassa brāhmaṇamahāsālā negamā ceva jānapadā ca dānāni paṭṭhapesuṁ.
root_text.dn5:20.4: Uttarena yaññavāṭassa gahapatinecayikā negamā ceva jānapadā ca dānāni paṭṭhapesuṁ.
root_text.dn5:20.5: Tesupi kho, brāhmaṇa, yaññesu neva gāvo haññiṁsu, na ajeḷakā haññiṁsu, na kukkuṭasūkarā haññiṁsu, na vividhā pāṇā saṅghātaṁ āpajjiṁsu, na rukkhā chijjiṁsu yūpatthāya, na dabbhā lūyiṁsu barihisatthāya.
root_text.dn5:20.6: Yepi nesaṁ ahesuṁ dāsāti vā pessāti vā kammakarāti vā, tepi na daṇḍatajjitā na bhayatajjitā na assumukhā rudamānā parikammāni akaṁsu.
root_text.dn5:20.7: Atha kho ye icchiṁsu, te akaṁsu, ye na icchiṁsu, na te akaṁsu;
root_text.dn5:20.8: yaṁ icchiṁsu, taṁ akaṁsu, yaṁ na icchiṁsu na taṁ akaṁsu.
root_text.dn5:20.10: Iti cattāro ca anumatipakkhā, rājā mahāvijito aṭṭhahaṅgehi samannāgato, purohito brāhmaṇo catūhaṅgehi samannāgato;
root_text.dn5:20.12: Ayaṁ vuccati, brāhmaṇa, tividhā yaññasampadā soḷasaparikkhārā”ti.
root_text.dn5:21.1: Evaṁ vutte, te brāhmaṇā unnādino uccāsaddamahāsaddā ahesuṁ:
root_text.dn5:21.3: Kūṭadanto pana brāhmaṇo tūṇhībhūtova nisinno hoti.
root_text.dn5:21.4: Atha kho te brāhmaṇā kūṭadantaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.dn5:21.5: “kasmā pana bhavaṁ kūṭadanto samaṇassa gotamassa subhāsitaṁ subhāsitato nābbhanumodatī”ti?
root_text.dn5:21.6: “Nāhaṁ, bho, samaṇassa gotamassa subhāsitaṁ subhāsitato nābbhanumodāmi.
root_text.dn5:21.7: Muddhāpi tassa vipateyya, yo samaṇassa gotamassa subhāsitaṁ subhāsitato nābbhanumodeyya.
root_text.dn5:21.8: Api ca me, bho, evaṁ hoti—
root_text.dn5:21.10: ‘evaṁ me sutan’ti vā ‘evaṁ arahati bhavitun’ti vā;
root_text.dn5:21.12: ‘evaṁ tadā āsi, itthaṁ tadā āsi’ tveva bhāsati.
root_text.dn5:21.14: ‘addhā samaṇo gotamo tena samayena rājā vā ahosi mahāvijito yaññassāmi purohito vā brāhmaṇo tassa yaññassa yājetā’ti.
root_text.dn5:21.15: Abhijānāti pana bhavaṁ gotamo evarūpaṁ yaññaṁ yajitvā vā yājetvā vā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjitā”ti?
root_text.dn5:21.16: “Abhijānāmahaṁ, brāhmaṇa, evarūpaṁ yaññaṁ yajitvā vā yājetvā vā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapajjitā, ahaṁ tena samayena purohito brāhmaṇo ahosiṁ tassa yaññassa yājetā”ti.
root_text.dn5:22.1: “Atthi pana, bho gotama, añño yañño imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṁsataro cā”ti?
root_text.dn5:22.2: “Atthi kho, brāhmaṇa, añño yañño imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṁsataro cā”ti.
root_text.dn5:22.3: “Katamo pana so, bho gotama, yañño imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṁsataro cā”ti?
root_text.dn5:22.4: “Yāni kho pana tāni, brāhmaṇa, niccadānāni anukulayaññāni sīlavante pabbajite uddissa diyyanti;
root_text.dn5:22.5: ayaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṁsataro cā”ti.
root_text.dn5:23.1: “Ko nu kho, bho gotama, hetu ko paccayo, yena taṁ niccadānaṁ anukulayaññaṁ imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhatarañca appasamārambhatarañca mahapphalatarañca mahānisaṁsatarañcā”ti?
root_text.dn5:23.2: “Na kho, brāhmaṇa, evarūpaṁ yaññaṁ upasaṅkamanti arahanto vā arahattamaggaṁ vā samāpannā.
root_text.dn5:23.4: Dissanti hettha, brāhmaṇa, daṇḍappahārāpi galaggahāpi, tasmā evarūpaṁ yaññaṁ na upasaṅkamanti arahanto vā arahattamaggaṁ vā samāpannā.
root_text.dn5:23.5: Yāni kho pana tāni, brāhmaṇa, niccadānāni anukulayaññāni sīlavante pabbajite uddissa diyyanti;
root_text.dn5:23.6: evarūpaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, yaññaṁ upasaṅkamanti arahanto vā arahattamaggaṁ vā samāpannā.
root_text.dn5:23.8: Na hettha, brāhmaṇa, dissanti daṇḍappahārāpi galaggahāpi, tasmā evarūpaṁ yaññaṁ upasaṅkamanti arahanto vā arahattamaggaṁ vā samāpannā.
root_text.dn5:23.9: Ayaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, hetu ayaṁ paccayo, yena taṁ niccadānaṁ anukulayaññaṁ imāya tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya appaṭṭhatarañca appasamārambhatarañca mahapphalatarañca mahānisaṁsatarañcā”ti.

root_text.dn5:24.3: “Katamo pana so, bho gotama, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṁsataro cā”ti?
root_text.dn5:24.4: “Yo kho, brāhmaṇa, cātuddisaṁ saṅghaṁ uddissa vihāraṁ karoti, ayaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, yañño imāya ca tividhāya yaññasampadāya soḷasaparikkhārāya iminā ca niccadānena anukulayaññena appaṭṭhataro ca appasamārambhataro ca mahapphalataro ca mahānisaṁsataro cā”ti.

root_text.dn5:28.1: Evaṁ vutte, kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn5:28.3: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṁ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
root_text.dn5:28.4: Esāhaṁ bhavantaṁ gotamaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
root_text.dn5:28.5: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gataṁ.
root_text.dn5:28.6: Esāhaṁ, bho gotama, satta ca usabhasatāni satta ca vacchatarasatāni satta ca vacchatarīsatāni satta ca ajasatāni satta ca urabbhasatāni muñcāmi, jīvitaṁ demi, haritāni ceva tiṇāni khādantu, sītāni ca pānīyāni pivantu, sīto ca nesaṁ vāto upavāyatū”ti.
root_text.dn5:29.1: Atha kho bhagavā kūṭadantassa brāhmaṇassa anupubbiṁ kathaṁ kathesi, seyyathidaṁ—
root_text.dn5:29.2: dānakathaṁ sīlakathaṁ saggakathaṁ; kāmānaṁ ādīnavaṁ okāraṁ saṅkilesaṁ nekkhamme ānisaṁsaṁ pakāsesi.
root_text.dn5:29.3: Yadā bhagavā aññāsi kūṭadantaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ kallacittaṁ muducittaṁ vinīvaraṇacittaṁ udaggacittaṁ pasannacittaṁ, atha yā buddhānaṁ sāmukkaṁsikā dhammadesanā, taṁ pakāsesi—
root_text.dn5:29.5: Seyyathāpi nāma suddhaṁ vatthaṁ apagatakāḷakaṁ sammadeva rajanaṁ paṭiggaṇheyya;
root_text.dn5:29.6: evameva kūṭadantassa brāhmaṇassa tasmiññeva āsane virajaṁ vītamalaṁ dhammacakkhuṁ udapādi:
root_text.dn5:30.1: Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo diṭṭhadhammo pattadhammo viditadhammo pariyogāḷhadhammo tiṇṇavicikiccho vigatakathaṅkatho vesārajjappatto aparappaccayo satthusāsane bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:

root_text.dn5:30.4: Atha kho kūṭadanto brāhmaṇo bhagavato adhivāsanaṁ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkāmi.

translation_text.dn5:1.0: 1. The Brahmins and Householders of Khāṇumata
translation_text.dn5:1.2: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Magadhans together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Magadhan brahmins named Khāṇumata.
translation_text.dn5:1.3: There he stayed nearby at Ambalaṭṭhikā.
translation_text.dn5:1.4: Now at that time the brahmin Kūṭadanta was living in Khāṇumata. It was a crown property given by King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal park endowed to a brahmin.
translation_text.dn5:1.5: Now at that time Kūṭadanta had prepared a great sacrifice.
translation_text.dn5:1.6: Bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats and rams—seven hundred of each—had been led to the post for the sacrifice.
translation_text.dn5:2.1: The brahmins and householders of Khāṇumata heard:
translation_text.dn5:2.2: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Khāṇumata and is staying at Ambalaṭṭhikā.
translation_text.dn5:2.4: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.dn5:2.5: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
translation_text.dn5:2.6: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
translation_text.dn5:2.7: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
translation_text.dn5:2.8: Then, exiting Khāṇumata, they formed into companies and headed to Ambalaṭṭhikā.
translation_text.dn5:3.1: Now at that time the brahmin Kūṭadanta had retired to the upper floor of his stilt longhouse for his midday nap.
translation_text.dn5:3.2: He saw the brahmins and householders heading for Ambalaṭṭhikā,
translation_text.dn5:3.4: “My butler, why are the brahmins and householders headed for Ambalaṭṭhikā?”
translation_text.dn5:3.5: “The ascetic Gotama has arrived at Khāṇumata and is staying at Ambalaṭṭhikā.
translation_text.dn5:3.7: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
translation_text.dn5:3.8: They’re going to see that worthy Gotama.”

translation_text.dn5:4.11: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied the butler, and did as he was asked.

translation_text.dn5:5.2: thinking to participate in Kūṭadanta’s sacrifice.
translation_text.dn5:5.4: Kūṭadanta was going to see the ascetic Gotama.
translation_text.dn5:5.5: They approached Kūṭadanta and said to him:
translation_text.dn5:5.6: “Is it really true that you are going to see the ascetic Gotama?”
translation_text.dn5:6.2: It’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama.
translation_text.dn5:6.3: For if you do so, your reputation will diminish and his will increase.
translation_text.dn5:6.4: For this reason it’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;
translation_text.dn5:6.5: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.
translation_text.dn5:6.6: You are well born on both your mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation.
translation_text.dn5:6.7: For this reason it’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;
translation_text.dn5:6.8: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.
translation_text.dn5:6.9: You’re rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of property and assets, and lots of money and grain …
translation_text.dn5:6.10: You recite and remember the hymns, and have mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. You know them word-by-word, and their grammar. You are well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man. …
translation_text.dn5:6.11: You are attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. You have divine looks and lustre, remarkable to behold. …
translation_text.dn5:6.12: You are ethical, mature in ethical conduct. …
translation_text.dn5:6.13: You’re a good speaker who enunciates well, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning. …
translation_text.dn5:6.14: You teach the tutors of many, and teach three hundred young students to recite the hymns. Many students come from various districts and countries for the sake of the hymns, wishing to learn the hymns. …
translation_text.dn5:6.15: You’re old, elderly and senior, advanced in years, and have reached the final stage of life.
translation_text.dn5:6.16: The ascetic Gotama is young, and has newly gone forth. …
translation_text.dn5:6.17: You’re honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed by King Bimbisāra of Magadha …
translation_text.dn5:6.19: You live in Khāṇumata, a crown property given by King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal park endowed to a brahmin.
translation_text.dn5:6.20: For this reason it’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;
translation_text.dn5:6.21: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.”
translation_text.dn5:7.1: When they had spoken, Kūṭadanta said to those brahmins:
translation_text.dn5:7.2: “Well then, gentlemen, listen to why it’s appropriate for me to go to see the ascetic Gotama,
translation_text.dn5:7.3: and it’s not appropriate for him to come to see me.
translation_text.dn5:7.4: He is well born on both his mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation.
translation_text.dn5:7.5: For this reason it’s not appropriate for the ascetic Gotama to come to see me;
translation_text.dn5:7.6: rather, it’s appropriate for me to go to see him.
translation_text.dn5:7.7: When he went forth he abandoned a large family circle. …
translation_text.dn5:7.8: When he went forth he abandoned abundant gold, both coined and uncoined, stored above and below ground. …
translation_text.dn5:7.9: He went forth from the lay life to homelessness while still a youth, young, with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life. …
translation_text.dn5:7.10: Though his mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces, he shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness. …
translation_text.dn5:7.11: He is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. He has divine looks and lustre, remarkable to behold. …
translation_text.dn5:7.12: He is ethical, possessing ethical conduct that is noble and skillful. …
translation_text.dn5:7.13: He’s a good speaker who enunciates well, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning. …
translation_text.dn5:7.15: He has ended sensual desire, and is rid of caprice. …
translation_text.dn5:7.16: He teaches the efficacy of deeds and action. He doesn’t wish any harm upon the community of brahmins. …
translation_text.dn5:7.17: He went forth from an eminent family of unbroken aristocratic lineage. …
translation_text.dn5:7.18: He went forth from a rich, affluent, and wealthy family. …
translation_text.dn5:7.19: People come from distant lands and distant countries to question him. …
translation_text.dn5:7.20: Many thousands of deities have gone for refuge for life to him. …
translation_text.dn5:7.22: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’ …
translation_text.dn5:7.23: He has the thirty-two marks of a great man. …
translation_text.dn5:7.24: He is welcoming, congenial, polite, smiling, open, the first to speak. …
translation_text.dn5:7.25: He’s honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed by the four assemblies. …
translation_text.dn5:7.26: Many gods and humans are devoted to him. …
translation_text.dn5:7.27: While he is residing in a village or town, non-human entities do not harass them. …
translation_text.dn5:7.28: He leads an order and a community, and tutors a community, and is said to be the best of the various religious founders. He didn’t come by his fame in the same ways as those other ascetics and brahmins.
translation_text.dn5:7.29: Rather, he came by his fame due to his supreme knowledge and conduct. …
translation_text.dn5:7.30: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. …
translation_text.dn5:7.31: King Pasenadi of Kosala and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. …
translation_text.dn5:7.32: The brahmin Pokkharasāti and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. …
translation_text.dn5:7.33: He’s honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed by King Bimbisāra of Magadha …
translation_text.dn5:7.36: The ascetic Gotama has arrived at Khāṇumata and is staying at Ambalaṭṭhikā.
translation_text.dn5:7.37: Any ascetic or brahmin who comes to stay in our village district is our guest,
translation_text.dn5:7.38: and should be honored and respected as such.
translation_text.dn5:7.41: For this reason, too, it’s not appropriate for the worthy Gotama to come to see me,
translation_text.dn5:7.42: rather, it’s appropriate for me to go to see him.
translation_text.dn5:7.43: This is the extent of the worthy Gotama’s praise that I have memorized. But his praises are not confined to this,
translation_text.dn5:7.44: for the praise of the worthy Gotama is limitless.”
translation_text.dn5:7.45: When he had spoken, those brahmins said to him,
translation_text.dn5:7.46: “According to Kūṭadanta’s praises, if the worthy Gotama were staying within a hundred leagues, it’d be worthwhile for a faithful gentleman to go to see him, even if he had to carry his own provisions in a knapsack.”
translation_text.dn5:7.47: “Well then, gentlemen, let’s all go to see the ascetic Gotama.”

translation_text.dn5:8.1: Then Kūṭadanta together with a large group of brahmins went to see the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.dn5:8.2: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
translation_text.dn5:8.3: Before sitting down to one side, some of the brahmins and householders of Khāṇumata bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.

translation_text.dn5:10.1: “Once upon a time, brahmin, there was a king named Mahāvijita. He was rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of gold and silver, lots of property and assets, lots of money and grain, and a full treasury and storehouses.
translation_text.dn5:10.2: Then as King Mahāvijita was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:
translation_text.dn5:10.3: ‘I have achieved human wealth, and reign after conquering this vast territory. Why don’t I hold a large sacrifice? That will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.’
translation_text.dn5:10.4: Then he summoned the brahmin high priest and said to him:
translation_text.dn5:10.5: ‘Just now, brahmin, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind,
translation_text.dn5:10.6: “I have achieved human wealth, and reign after conquering this vast territory. Why don’t I perform a great sacrifice? That will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
translation_text.dn5:10.7: Brahmin, I wish to perform a great sacrifice.
translation_text.dn5:10.8: Please instruct me. It will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.’
translation_text.dn5:11.1: When he had spoken, the brahmin high priest said to him:
translation_text.dn5:11.2: ‘Sir, the king’s realm is harried and oppressed. Raiding of villages, towns, and cities has been seen, and infesting of highways.
translation_text.dn5:11.3: But if the king were to extract more taxes while his realm is thus harried and oppressed, he would not be doing his duty.
translation_text.dn5:11.5: “I’ll eradicate this plague of savages by execution or imprisonment or confiscation or condemnation or banishment!” But that’s not the right way to eradicate this plague of savages.
translation_text.dn5:11.6: Those who remain after the killing will return to harass the king’s realm.
translation_text.dn5:11.7: Rather, here is a plan, relying on which the plague of savages will be properly uprooted.
translation_text.dn5:11.8: So let the king provide seed and fodder for those in the realm who work in growing crops and raising cattle.
translation_text.dn5:11.9: Let the king provide funding for those who work in trade.
translation_text.dn5:11.10: Let the king guarantee food and wages for those in government service.
translation_text.dn5:11.11: Then the people, occupied with their own work, will not harass the realm.
translation_text.dn5:11.12: The king’s revenues will be great.
translation_text.dn5:11.13: When the country is secured as a sanctuary, free of being harried and oppressed, the happy people, with joy in their hearts, dancing with children at their breast, will dwell as if their houses were wide open.’
translation_text.dn5:11.14: The king agreed with the high priest’s advice and followed his recommendation.
translation_text.dn5:11.19: Then the king summoned the brahmin high priest and said to him:
translation_text.dn5:11.20: ‘I have eradicated the plague of savages. And relying on your plan my revenue is now great.
translation_text.dn5:11.21: Since the country is secured as a sanctuary, free of being harried and oppressed, the happy people, with joy in their hearts, dancing with children at their breast, dwell as if their houses were wide open.
translation_text.dn5:11.22: Brahmin, I wish to perform a great sacrifice.
translation_text.dn5:11.23: Please instruct me. It will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.’
translation_text.dn5:12.1: ‘In that case, let the king announce this throughout the realm to the aristocrat vassals of both town and country; the ministers and councillors of both town and country; the well-to-do brahmins of both town and country; and the well-off householders of both town and country.
translation_text.dn5:12.2: “I wish to perform a great sacrifice. Please grant your approval, good fellows; it will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
translation_text.dn5:12.3: The king agreed with the high priest’s advice and followed his recommendation.
translation_text.dn5:12.4: And all of the people who were thus informed responded by saying:
translation_text.dn5:12.5: ‘May the king perform a sacrifice! It is time for a sacrifice, great king.’
translation_text.dn5:12.9: And so these four consenting factions became accessories to the sacrifice.

translation_text.dn5:15.1: Next, before the sacrifice, the brahmin high priest taught the three modes to the king.
translation_text.dn5:15.2: ‘Now, though the king wants to perform a great sacrifice, he might have certain regrets, thinking:
translation_text.dn5:15.3: “I shall lose a great fortune,” or
translation_text.dn5:15.5: “I am losing a great fortune,” or
translation_text.dn5:15.7: “I have lost a great fortune.” But the king should not harbor such regrets.’
translation_text.dn5:15.8: These are the three modes that the brahmin high priest taught to the king before the sacrifice.
translation_text.dn5:16.1: Next, before the sacrifice, the brahmin high priest dispelled the king’s regret regarding the recipients in ten respects:
translation_text.dn5:16.2: ‘There will come to the sacrifice those who kill living creatures and those who refrain from killing living creatures.
translation_text.dn5:16.3: As to those who kill living creatures, the outcome of that is theirs alone.
translation_text.dn5:16.4: But as to those who refrain from killing living creatures, it is for their sakes that the king should sacrifice, relinquish, rejoice, and gain confidence in his heart.
translation_text.dn5:16.5: There will come to the sacrifice those who steal …
translation_text.dn5:16.13: have wrong view and those who have right view.
translation_text.dn5:16.14: As to those who have wrong view, the outcome of that is theirs alone.
translation_text.dn5:16.15: But as to those who have right view, it is for their sakes that the king should sacrifice, relinquish, rejoice, and gain confidence in his heart.’
translation_text.dn5:16.16: These are the ten respects in which the high priest dispelled the king’s regret regarding the recipients before the sacrifice.
translation_text.dn5:17.1: Next, while the king was performing the great sacrifice, the brahmin high priest educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired the king’s mind in sixteen respects:
translation_text.dn5:17.2: ‘Now, while the king is performing the great sacrifice, someone might say,
translation_text.dn5:17.3: “King Mahāvijita performs a great sacrifice, but he did not announce it to the aristocrat vassals of town and country.
translation_text.dn5:17.4: That’s the kind of great sacrifice that this king performs.”
translation_text.dn5:17.5: Those who speak against the king in this way have no legitimacy.
translation_text.dn5:17.6: For the king did indeed announce it to the aristocrat vassals of town and country.
translation_text.dn5:17.7: Let the king know this as a reason to sacrifice, relinquish, rejoice, and gain confidence in his heart.
translation_text.dn5:17.8: While the king is performing the great sacrifice, someone might say,

translation_text.dn5:17.12: Let the king know this too as a reason to sacrifice, relinquish, rejoice, and gain confidence in his heart.

translation_text.dn5:17.29: Let the king know this too as a reason to sacrifice, relinquish, rejoice, and gain confidence in his heart.

translation_text.dn5:17.42: Those who speak against the king in this way have no legitimacy.
translation_text.dn5:17.43: For the high priest does indeed possess the four factors.

translation_text.dn5:18.1: And brahmin, in that sacrifice no cattle were killed, no goats or sheep were killed, and no chickens or pigs were killed. There was no slaughter of various kinds of creatures. No trees were felled for the sacrificial post. No grass was reaped to strew over the place of sacrifice.
translation_text.dn5:18.2: No bondservants, servants, or workers did their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces.
translation_text.dn5:18.3: Those who wished to work did so, while those who did not wish to did not.
translation_text.dn5:18.4: They did the work they wanted to, and did not do what they didn’t want to.
translation_text.dn5:18.5: The sacrifice was completed with just ghee, oil, butter, curds, honey, and molasses.
translation_text.dn5:19.1: Then the aristocrat vassals, ministers and councillors, well-to-do brahmins, and well-off householders came to the king bringing abundant wealth and said,
translation_text.dn5:19.2: ‘Sire, this abundant wealth is specially for you alone; may Your Highness accept it!’
translation_text.dn5:19.3: ‘There’s enough raised for me through regular taxes. Let this be for you; and here, take even more!’
translation_text.dn5:19.5: When the king turned them down, they withdrew to one side to think up a plan,
translation_text.dn5:19.6: ‘It wouldn’t be proper for us to take this abundant wealth back to our own homes.
translation_text.dn5:19.7: King Mahāvijita is performing a great sacrifice. Let us make an offering as an auxiliary sacrifice.’

translation_text.dn5:20.9: The sacrifice was completed with just ghee, oil, butter, curds, honey, and molasses.
translation_text.dn5:20.10: And so there were four consenting factions, eight factors possessed by King Mahāvijita, four factors possessed by the high priest,
translation_text.dn5:20.12: Brahmin, this is called the sacrifice accomplished with three modes and sixteen accessories.”
translation_text.dn5:21.1: When he said this, those brahmins made an uproar,
translation_text.dn5:21.2: “Hooray for such sacrifice! Hooray for the accomplishment of such sacrifice!”
translation_text.dn5:21.3: But the brahmin Kūṭadanta sat in silence.
translation_text.dn5:21.4: So those brahmins said to him,
translation_text.dn5:21.5: “How can you not applaud the ascetic Gotama’s fine words?”
translation_text.dn5:21.6: “It’s not that I don’t applaud what he said.
translation_text.dn5:21.7: If anyone didn’t applaud such fine words, their head would explode!
translation_text.dn5:21.8: But, gentlemen, it occurs to me that
translation_text.dn5:21.9: the ascetic Gotama does not say:
translation_text.dn5:21.10: ‘So I have heard’ or ‘It ought to be like this.’
translation_text.dn5:21.12: ‘So it was then, this is how it was then.’
translation_text.dn5:21.14: the ascetic Gotama at that time must have been King Mahāvijita, the owner of the sacrifice, or else the brahmin high priest who facilitated the sacrifice for him.
translation_text.dn5:21.15: Does the worthy Gotama recall having performed such a sacrifice, or having facilitated it, and then, when his body broke up, after death, being reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm?”
translation_text.dn5:21.16: “I do recall that, brahmin. For I myself was the brahmin high priest at that time who facilitated the sacrifice.”
translation_text.dn5:22.0: 5. A Regular Gift as an Propitious Sacrifice.
translation_text.dn5:22.1: “But Mister Gotama, apart from that sacrifice accomplished with three modes and sixteen accessories, is there any other sacrifice that has fewer obligations and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial?”
translation_text.dn5:22.4: “The regular gifts as propitious sacrifice given specially to ethical renunciates;
translation_text.dn5:22.5: this sacrifice, brahmin, has fewer obligations and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial.”
translation_text.dn5:23.1: “What is the cause, Mister Gotama, what is the reason why those regular gifts as propitious sacrifice have fewer obligations and undertakings, yet are more fruitful and beneficial, compared with the sacrifice accomplished with three modes and sixteen accessories?”
translation_text.dn5:23.2: “Because neither perfected ones nor those who are on the path to perfection will attend such a sacrifice.
translation_text.dn5:23.4: Because beatings and throttlings are seen there.
translation_text.dn5:23.5: But the regular gifts as propitious sacrifice given specially to ethical renunciates;
translation_text.dn5:23.6: perfected ones and those who are on the path to perfection will attend such a sacrifice.
translation_text.dn5:23.8: Because no beatings and throttlings are seen there.
translation_text.dn5:23.9: This is the cause, brahmin, this is the reason why those regular gifts as propitious sacrifice have fewer obligations and undertakings, yet are more fruitful and beneficial, compared with the sacrifice accomplished with three modes and sixteen accessories.”
translation_text.dn5:24.1: “But Mister Gotama, apart from that sacrifice accomplished with three modes and sixteen accessories and those regular gifts as propitious sacrifice, is there any other sacrifice that has fewer obligations and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial?”
translation_text.dn5:24.4: “When someone gives a dwelling specially for the Saṅgha of the four quarters.”
translation_text.dn5:25.1: “But is there any other sacrifice that has fewer obligations and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial?”
translation_text.dn5:25.4: “When someone with confident heart goes for refuge to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.”
translation_text.dn5:26.1: “But is there any other sacrifice that has fewer obligations and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial?”
translation_text.dn5:26.4: “When someone with a confident heart undertakes the training rules
translation_text.dn5:26.5: to refrain from killing living creatures, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, and beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.”
translation_text.dn5:27.1: “But is there any other sacrifice that has fewer obligations and undertakings, yet is more fruitful and beneficial?”
translation_text.dn5:27.4: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha …
translation_text.dn5:27.5: That’s how a mendicant is accomplished in ethics. …
translation_text.dn5:27.6: They enter and remain in the first absorption …
translation_text.dn5:27.7: This sacrifice has fewer obligations and undertakings than the former, yet is more fruitful and beneficial. …
translation_text.dn5:27.8: They enter and remain in the second absorption …
translation_text.dn5:27.11: This sacrifice has fewer obligations and undertakings than the former, yet is more fruitful and beneficial. …
translation_text.dn5:27.12: They project and extend the mind toward knowledge and vision …
translation_text.dn5:27.13: This sacrifice has fewer obligations and undertakings than the former, yet is more fruitful and beneficial.
translation_text.dn5:27.14: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’
translation_text.dn5:27.15: This sacrifice has fewer obligations and undertakings than the former, yet is more fruitful and beneficial.
translation_text.dn5:27.16: And, brahmin, there is no other accomplishment of sacrifice which is better and finer than this.”
translation_text.dn5:28.0: 6. Kūṭadanta Declares Himself a Lay Follower
translation_text.dn5:28.1: When he had spoken, Kūṭadanta said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn5:28.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways.
translation_text.dn5:28.4: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.dn5:28.5: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
translation_text.dn5:28.6: And these bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, and rams—seven hundred of each—I release them, I grant them life! Let them eat green grass and drink cool water, and may a cool breeze blow upon them!”
translation_text.dn5:29.0: 7. The Realization of the Fruit of Stream-Entry
translation_text.dn5:29.1: Then the Buddha taught Kūṭadanta step by step, with
translation_text.dn5:29.2: a talk on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven. He explained the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, so sordid and corrupt, and the benefit of renunciation.
translation_text.dn5:29.3: And when he knew that Kūṭadanta’s mind was ready, pliable, rid of hindrances, elated, and confident he explained the special teaching of the Buddhas:
translation_text.dn5:29.4: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
translation_text.dn5:29.5: Just as a clean cloth rid of stains would properly absorb dye,
translation_text.dn5:29.6: in that very seat the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in the brahmin Kūṭadanta:
translation_text.dn5:29.7: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”
translation_text.dn5:30.1: Then Kūṭadanta saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. He went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. He said to the Buddha,
translation_text.dn5:30.2: “Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”
translation_text.dn5:30.4: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Kūṭadanta got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
translation_text.dn5:30.5: And when the night had passed Kūṭadanta had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own sacrificial enclosure. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
translation_text.dn5:30.6: “It’s time, worthy Gotama, the meal is ready.”
translation_text.dn5:30.7: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the sacrificial enclosure of Kūṭadanta together with the mendicant Saṅgha, where he sat on the seat spread out.
translation_text.dn5:30.8: Then Kūṭadanta served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
translation_text.dn5:30.9: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Kūṭadanta took a low seat and sat to one side.
translation_text.dn5:30.10: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.
